  2
  3/** @file    vsip/core/refcount.hpp
  4    @author  Jules Bergmann
  5    @date    2005-01-24
  6    @brief   VSIPL++ Library: Reference count base class.
  7
  8    Classes requiring reference counts should derive from Ref_count.
  9
 10    Notes:
 11    [1] Ref_count is templated on the type of the derived class.
 12        This allows it to call the derived class destructor when
 13        the reference count goes to zero (without declaring the
 14	destructor virtual).  However, this means that Ref_count
 15	should only be used when the static_cast is safe.  This
 16	precludes multiple inheritence and more then level of
 17        additional inheritence that overrides the destructor.
 18
 19    [2] Class Ref_count declares count_ as mutable.  This allows the
 20        increment_count() and decrement_count() members to preserve
 21        const-ness.  This is necessary since it is possible to create
 22        a reference to a const blocks (for example, creating a
 23        subview).
 24*/
 25
 26
 27#ifndef VSIP_CORE_REFCOUNT_HPP
 28#define VSIP_CORE_REFCOUNT_HPP
 29
 30/***********************************************************************
 31  Included Files
 32***********************************************************************/

 34#include <vsip/core/counter.hpp>
 35#include <vsip/core/noncopyable.hpp>

 39/***********************************************************************
 40  Declarations

 43namespace vsip
 44{
 45
 46namespace impl
 47{
 48
 49/// Reference counting base class.
 50
 51/// Ref_count has the following behavior:
 52///  - when constructed, reference count starts out at one.
 53///  - when increment_count is called, the reference count is
 54///    incremented.
 55///  - when decrement_count is called, the reference count is
 56///    decremented, and checked against 0.  If the count is
 57///    0, the destructor of the derived class is called.
 58///
 59
 60template <typename DerivedClass>
 61class Ref_count
 62{
 63  // Constructors.
 64public:
 65  Ref_count() VSIP_NOTHROW : count_(1) {}
 66
 67  // Accessors
 68public:
 69  void increment_count() const;
 70  void decrement_count() const;
 71
 72  // Debug interface
 73public:
 74  unsigned impl_debug_count() const { return count_.value(); }
 75
 76  // Hidden Functions.
 77  // Reference-counted objects should not be copied by value, rather a
 78  // new reference should be created (and the count incremented).
 79private:
 80  Ref_count(Ref_count const&);
 81  Ref_count& operator=(Ref_count const&);
 82
 83  // Member Data.
 84private:
 85  mutable Checked_counter count_;
 86};
 87
 88/// Type and valueused as the second argument to a Ref_counted_ptr
 89/// constructor to indicate that it should not increment the object's
 90/// reference count.  This is purely a flag, rather like std::nothrow.
 91enum noincrement_type { noincrement };
 92
 93/// Smart pointer to a reference counted object.
 94
 95/// Ref_counted_ptr must be instantiated with a type that implements the
 96/// above Ref_count interface.  When constructed with an instance of
 97/// that type, you may specify whether or not the refcount of that
 98/// object should be incremented.  Copy-initialization and assignment
 99/// always increment the reference count of the now-pointed-to object,
100/// and decrement that of the no-longer-pointed-to object if any.
101/// When destructed, the refcount is always decremented.
102///
103/// Pointer arithmetic is not supported.
104///
105/// In all other regards Ref_counted_ptr<T> behaves as T*.
106
107template <typename Obj>
108class Ref_counted_ptr
109{
110  Obj* ptr_;  ///< Underlying pointer.
111
112public:
113  typedef Obj& equiv_type;
114
115  /// Basic constructor from an object.  This takes a pointer to the object
116  /// so that you write "Ref_counted_ptr<T> ptr(&obj)" just like an ordinary
117  /// pointer.
118  explicit
119  Ref_counted_ptr(Obj *p) : ptr_(p) { ptr_->increment_count(); }
120
121  /// Variant constructor which does not increment the reference count.
122  /// This is useful when the object has just been constructed, so it
123  /// already has a reference count of 1, and this is the sole handle.
124  Ref_counted_ptr(Obj *p, noincrement_type) VSIP_NOTHROW : ptr_(p) {}
125
126  /// Copy-constructor, always increments the reference count.
127  Ref_counted_ptr(Ref_counted_ptr const& p) : ptr_(p.ptr_)
128    { ptr_->increment_count(); }
129
130  /// Destructor.
131  ~Ref_counted_ptr() { ptr_->decrement_count(); }
132
133  /// operator= always increments the reference count of the new object
134  /// and decrements the reference count of the old object.
135  Ref_counted_ptr&
136  operator=(Ref_counted_ptr const& from)
137    {
138      if (ptr_ != from.ptr_)
139      {
140        ptr_->decrement_count();
141        ptr_ = from.ptr_;
142        ptr_->increment_count();
143      }
144      return *this;
145    }
146
147  /// Dereference operator.
148  Obj&
149  operator*() const VSIP_NOTHROW
150    { return *ptr_; }
151
152  /// Arrow operator.
153  Obj*
154  operator->() const VSIP_NOTHROW
155    { return ptr_; }
156
157  /// An accessor for situations where you need a raw pointer.
158  Obj*
159  get() const VSIP_NOTHROW
160    { return ptr_; }
161};
162
163
164
165/// Smart pointer to a reference counted object, using policy for 
166/// increment and decrement.
167
168/// RPPtr must be instantiated with a type that implements a Ref_count
169/// interface accessed via a Ref_count policy RP.  When constructed
170/// with an instance of that type, you may specify whether or not the
171/// refcount of that object should be incremented.
172/// Copy-initialization and assignment always increment the reference
173/// count of the now-pointed-to object, and decrement that of the
174/// no-longer-pointed-to object if any.  When destructed, the refcount
175/// is always decremented.
176///
177/// Pointer arithmetic is not supported.
178///
179/// In all other regards RPPtr<T> behaves as T*.
180
181template <typename Obj,
182	  typename RP>
183class RPPtr
184{
185  Obj* ptr_;  ///< Underlying pointer.
186
187public:
188  /// Basic constructor from an object.  This takes a pointer to the object
189  /// so that you write "RPPtr<T> ptr(&obj)" just like an ordinary
190  /// pointer.
191  explicit
192  RPPtr(Obj *p) : ptr_(p)
193    { RP::inc(ptr_); }
194
195  /// Variant constructor which does not increment the reference count.
196  /// This is useful when the object has just been constructed, so it
197  /// already has a reference count of 1, and this is the sole handle.
198  RPPtr(Obj *p, noincrement_type) VSIP_NOTHROW : ptr_(p) {}
199
200  /// Copy-constructor, always increments the reference count.
201  RPPtr(RPPtr const& p) : ptr_(p.ptr_)
202    { RP::inc(ptr_); }
203
204  /// Destructor.
205  ~RPPtr() { RP::dec(ptr_); }
206
207  /// operator= always increments the reference count of the new object
208  /// and decrements the reference count of the old object.
209  RPPtr&
210  operator=(RPPtr const& from)
211    {
212      RP::dec(ptr_);
213      ptr_ = from.ptr_;
214      RP::inc(ptr_);
215      return *this;
216    }
217
218  /// Dereference operator.
219  Obj&
220  operator*() const VSIP_NOTHROW
221    { return *ptr_; }
222
223  /// Arrow operator.
224  Obj*
225  operator->() const VSIP_NOTHROW
226    { return ptr_; }
227
228  /// An accessor for situations where you need a raw pointer.
229  Obj*
230  get() const VSIP_NOTHROW
231    { return ptr_; }
232};
233
234/// Store a mutable object.
235
236// Mutable hosts an object by value, but uses a mutable data member,
237// unless the object is const, since const objects cannot be mutable.
238
239template <typename Obj>
240class Mutable
241{
242public:
243  // Constructor.
244  Mutable(Obj& data) : data_(data) {}
245 
246  Obj& get() const { return data_; }
247
248private:
249  mutable Obj data_;
250};
251
252template <typename Obj>
253class Mutable<const Obj>
254{
255public:
256  // Constructor.
257  Mutable(const Obj& data) : data_(data) {}
258
259  // Return a reference to the object.
260  const Obj& get() const { return data_; }
261 
262private:
263  const Obj data_;
264};
265
266/// Store object by value
267
268/// Stored_value holds an object by-value, but presents an interface
269/// similar to Ref_counted_ptr.  This allows views to use Stored_value
270/// and Ref_counted_ptr interchangably.
271///
272/// Stored_value does not call increment_count and decrement_count on
273/// stored value.
274///
275/// Note 050321: Making Stored_value Non_assignable and using default
276/// copy-constructor would work fine.  However, views do not use the
277/// copy-constructor directly, instead they construct a copy by
278/// dereferencing the original Stored_value and using the "Obj*"
279/// constructor.  Making Stored_value Non_copyable emphasizes this usage.
280
281template <typename Obj>
282class Stored_value : public Non_copyable
283{
284  // Constructors and destructor.
285public:
286  typedef Obj equiv_type;
287
288  /// Basic constructor from an object.  This takes a pointer to the object
289  /// so that you write "Stored_value<T> ptr(&obj)" just like Ref_counted_ptr.
290  explicit
291  Stored_value(Obj *p) : data_(*p) {}
292
293  /// Variant constructor to maintain interface compatibility with
294  /// Ref_counted_ptr.
295  Stored_value(Obj *p, noincrement_type) : data_(*p) {}
296
297  ~Stored_value() {}
298
299
300  // Accessors.
301public:
302  Obj& operator*() const VSIP_NOTHROW { return data_.get(); }
303  Obj* operator->() const VSIP_NOTHROW { return get(); }
304  Obj* get() const VSIP_NOTHROW { return &data_.get(); }
305
306  // Member data.
307private:
308  Mutable<Obj> data_; ///< Underlying stored value.
309};
310
311/***********************************************************************
312  Definitions
313***********************************************************************/
314
315/// Increment reference count.
316template <typename DerivedClass>
317inline void
318Ref_count<DerivedClass>::increment_count() const
319{
320  ++count_;
321}
322
323
324
325/// Decrement reference count and delete if it goes to zero.
326template <typename DerivedClass>
327inline void
328Ref_count<DerivedClass>::decrement_count() const
329{
330  // Since this function is const, it is first necessary to
331  // const_cast away const-ness, then static_cast to the derived
332  // type.
333  if (--count_ == 0)
334    delete static_cast<DerivedClass*>(const_cast<Ref_count*>(this));
335}
336
337
338
339/// Pass view through, while decrement reference count of a view's block
340/// (Useful for subview creation).
341
342template <typename View>
343View
344decrement_block_count(
345  View view)
346{
347  view.block().decrement_count();
348  return view;
349}
